item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

why is new JPanel(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER)); there? it’s not generally good programming practice to initialize a new, useless object and store it in the heap, even if it will be cleaned up sooner or later through the gc.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

Ahh thank you _cake. To be honest I’m really not thinking. I’ve set the “BorderLayout” to north, and yet it still does the same thing in the picture. My code now looks like this:

[code]package JavaAIO;

import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.FlowLayout;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;

public class GUI extends JFrame
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
new GUI();
}

public GUI() 
{
	this.setSize(350,300);
	this.setResizable(false);
	   this.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);	   
		this.setTitle("Server Tool - Tico135");
		
		JPanel panel1 = new JPanel(new BorderLayout(0,0));
		new JPanel(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));
		panel1.add(new JLabel("Welcome, please choose one of the options."), BorderLayout.NORTH);
		panel1.add(new JButton("Compile"), BorderLayout.NORTH);
		panel1.add(new JButton("Run"), BorderLayout.NORTH);
		panel1.add(new JButton("Links"), BorderLayout.NORTH);
		this.add(panel1);
		panel1.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));		
		this.setVisible(true);
		

}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

FlowLayout is like totally secksi, but sometimes it is better to integrate multiple layouts. But never set the layout to null unless you are planning on turning resizing off, otherwise the component will look really stupid when the window is minimized or maximized from its original stated.

Try the following:

JPanel panel1 = new JPanel(new BorderLayout(0, 0)), panel2 = new JPanel(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));
panel.add(new JLabel("message here..."), BorderLayout.NORTH);
panel2.add(new JButton("button1"));
panel2.add(new JButton("button2"));
panel2.add(new JButton("button3"));
panel.add(panel2, BorderLayout.SOUTH);
parent.add(panel);

This keeps the flow of the buttons but forces them to go underneath the label.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @_assign _assign
item.description:
@_assign wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:3, topic:162327”]To do that, set the LayoutManager to \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\‘null\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\’, and set all components bounds to wherever you want them.

[COMPONENT].setBounds(x, y);[/quote]You only use setBounds method when you have no LayoutManager, in this setBounds isn\'t needed since the manager calls setbounds by default. Tico just use netbeans or whatever for your gui.

EDIT: Wtf, why does isn’t come out as isn\'t?

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Ignore BAsh.

Using no LayoutManager is sometimes a lot easier that doing it properly, but it really isn’t encouraged. If you want your window to resize nicely, I suggest you use something like a GridBagLayout.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:4, topic:162327”]1) Install netbeans
2) Open netbeans and create a new project
3) Create a new GUI class
4) Add buttons and customize to heart’s content.
5) Switch to source view and copy and paste code into currently used editor.
6) Optimize (Optional)[/quote]

Bud, I know that stuff. Thanks for the help anyways. And thanks to you two above.

[quote=“ephemeral, post:3, topic:162327”]To do that, set the LayoutManager to ‘null’, and set all components bounds to wherever you want them.

[COMPONENT].setBounds(x, y);

How would I figure out the coordinates?

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

  1. Install netbeans
  2. Open netbeans and create a new project
  3. Create a new GUI class
  4. Add buttons and customize to heart’s content.
  5. Switch to source view and copy and paste code into currently used editor.
  6. Optimize (Optional)

Read full topic

item.title: GUI next line help
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

I’m making a GUI, button I’m running into a problem. I have the code set out correctly, the thing is, I have a label on top, and I want to have 1 button on each line below the label. I can’t overally think of it right now, so all help is appreciated.

Adding this code:

[code]
package JavaAIO;

import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.FlowLayout;
import java.io.;

public class GUI extends JFrame
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
new GUI();
}

public GUI() 
{
	this.setSize(350,300);
	this.setResizable(false);
	   this.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);	   
		this.setTitle("Server Tool - Tico135");			
		
		JPanel panel1 = new JPanel();
		JLabel label1 = new JLabel("Welcome, please choose one of the options."); //label
		JButton button1 = new JButton("Compile");
		JButton button2 = new JButton("Run");
		JButton button3 = new JButton("Links");
		this.add(panel1);
		panel1.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER));
		panel1.add(label1);	//adds the label
		panel1.add(button1);
		panel1.add(button2);
		panel1.add(button3);
		this.setVisible(true);

		
		
		
}

}[/code]

Gives me this:

Read full topic
